awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mathematics Immersion for Secondary Teachers at Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Current reforms in mathematics place new demands on teachers, changing the focus of the mathematics they teach focusing on what it means to do mathematics, not just learn facts and methods that are the results of the work of others. Teachers need strong professional development to meet these new demands. The goal of this project will be to provide the field with a cost-effective model for intense content-based professional development in ways that have not been possible before, except through costly face-to-face models, by creating and testing design principles for blended online courses. Team members will design, implement, and research the effects of a professional development immersion experience in mathematics for practicing secondary teachers (grades 7-12). The project will provide mathematics immersion experience to over 300 teachers at 56 sites across the country. Over the course of two years, each of 14 instructors will work with four geographically separated groups of 4-7 teachers, engaging them in mathematics as learners and facilitating conversations that connect the experience to their teaching and professional work. The project will provide the field a concrete model for modern practice-based mathematics immersion, conducted at scale. The model has the potential to broaden participation in immersive professional development experiences, offering opportunities to greater numbers of teachers and expanding the diversity of school contexts affected. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The research questions will investigate fidelity of course implementation and differences in enactment. RQ1. How well can instructors enact the blended course design with fidelity and create immersion experiences in mathematics for participating teachers? RQ2.What variations exist among instructors' enactment of the courses? What explains differences in enactment, and how do they relate to teachers' experiences in the courses? RQ3. What is the impact of the professional development on teachers' (a) mathematical habits of mind, (b) beliefs about the nature of mathematics and mathematics teaching, and (c) engagement in their professional mathematics community? RQ4. What is the impact of the professional development on teachers' instructional practices, particularly on the types of investigative mathematics learning experiences that teachers provide for students? The project will use established measures to research the effects of these experiences on teachers' content knowledge, mathematical habits of mind, beliefs about mathematics, involvement in a professional community, and teaching practices. The first two research questions will be answered through qualitative data analysis of session enactment logs, video-recorded course sessions, and interviews. The second two research questions will be addressed through repeated measures analysis, with all teachers assessed three times over the course of the project. For research question 3, the outcome measures will be total and scale scores of the measures of teachers' knowledge, preparedness to teach mathematics, and beliefs. Additionally, qualitative analysis of interview data will explore trends in the frequency and nature of teachers' engagement over time. For research question 4, the outcome measures will be teaching practices with qualitative analysis of observations and interviews.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematics Immersion for Secondary Teachers at Scale (MISTaS) was a 4-year collaborative research project between Education Development Center (EDC) and Horizon Research, Incorporated (HRI). EDC has a long history of offering Professional Development (PD) that engages teachers in learning more mathematics by immersing themselves in doing mathematics – largely for fun. These programs have typically been offered as weeks-long residential programs during summer months requiring an investment of money and a large amount of consolidated time. Participants have shared that they enjoy the mathematics, the collaborative learning and the communities that result. In MISTaS, the goal was to develop and test a model of virtual connection that would maintain the benefits of these face-to-face sessions while mitigating the investment of money and consolidated time.

The model used for our PD—Mathematics Immersion for Secondary Teachers (MIST)—was previously shown viable through Electronic Communities of Mathematics Instruction (e-CMI; NSF Grant No. 1316246). A few (4 – 7) teachers from a school or community—a site—would gather in one room while being logged into a video conference with 2 – 3 other sites and a facilitator. These sites would be analogous to teachers working at different tables in a face-to-face PD session, but in MIST, these “tables” are located across the country. This setup allowed for the collaborative learning without the need for teachers to travel farther than another classroom or the local library.  The connection to other sites and a facilitator allowed for networking and community building that are an important part of professional development for teachers.

Many PD programs offer training on an instructional technique or implementing a new curriculum. As an  alternative, MIST consisted of nine 2.5-hour sessions where participants were presented with a coherent set of mathematics problems in which they immersed themselves. These problem sets are very intentionally crafted to provide access for virtually any level of mathematical experience and to allow for exploration and discovery of mathematical content, rather than practicing a process demonstrated by a teacher. Through this exploration, participants delved into the concepts, working collaboratively to make connections from one session’s content to that of other sessions. Consequently, the facilitation of these explorations was about allowing for productive struggle and independent discovery, prompting the collaboration, and intervening only when a group got stuck. Each session also contained a reflective discussion of the pedagogical connections to the classroom providing opportunities for networking through the sharing of ideas.

We engaged approximately 300 teachers in MIST over 2 school years. These teachers represent 12 states and nearly 30 schools and districts. One unanticipated benefit that teachers shared anecdotally is that when the pandemic hit, they were more familiar with online platforms and remote instructional techniques.

To reach this many teachers, we trained 15 educators from a broad spectrum of roles—classroom teachers, instructional coaches, and college faculty—to be facilitators. These facilitators learned and practiced instruction through exploration and discovery while also deepening their understanding of the mathematical content and consequently earned a badge from EDC, through Credly, for “Online Immersive Mathematics Facilitation”. Through this group we now have a cadre of people in roles with significant networks—department chairs, curriculum developers and one with a nationwide following of over 8,000.

In addition to the MIST courses in the project, our dissemination efforts included opportunities for a wide variety of participants. We collaborated with STEM Opportunities in Prison Settings (STEM-OPS; INCLUDES-1931045) offering an immersion course to ~20 college level instructors teaching in prisons introducing them to this style of learning and facilitation. Some of these participants said this was the best training they had experienced..

Another effort included substituting a course for a face-to-face offering that got cancelled due to COVID. Through this we learned people are willing to pay a nominal fee for this type of experience. Our third venture offered a behind-the-scenes look at the development of the problem sets which engaged ~25 MIST participants in creating a MIST-style problem set for their own classroom.

In e-CMI, the model was developed and tested with one group of 4 sites. The primary research goal of MISTaS was to implement the model on a larger scale and investigate its feasibility. The questions the project strove to answer are:

  1. How well can newly trained instructors enact the course design with fidelity and create immersion experiences for participants?
  2. How do different instructors modify the model and how does this affect the experience?
  3. What is the impact of MIST on teacher’s mathematical knowledge and approaches and beliefs about mathematics learning and instruction?
  4. What is the impact of MIST on teachers’ practices, particularly on the types of learning experiences they provide?

The analysis of these data is ongoing, but there are some early positive results. Full results will be available from Horizon Research, Inc. through DRL-1719554.The website is mist.edc.org and houses more information and examples.
